posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My honest opinion after seeing the preview at 7:45 pm showtime in open caption, 3D, HFR

Good:

Amazing visuals. The best 3D presentation ever since, yes, Avatar the first movie I saw in IMAX 3D 70mm when it came out

Clever homages to Jim's prior films -- Aliens, The Abyss, T2, True Lies and even fucking Titanic, lol

Good storytelling, fuck the cynics and haters like Film Threat's Chris Gore, Critical Drinker and even the snobby British critics who don't know what joy of moviegoing even fucking mean.

Not a single minute wasted in bump of pacing rhythm that might feel boring. Just good entertainment throughout with superb editing as always.

Bad:

HFR during the intense and fast-paced battle scenes is distracting with the fast forward effect.

Hey Jim, slow down to maybe 30 frames per second so the audience understand the action instead of being confused who gets killed what. I didn't realize the buddy-buddy villain Lyle died.

Great job, JAMES!

Hope you get to make 4th and 5th sequel, let's go and kick ass!

Picrel, meme created by me
While HFR

Chud is derived from Tjude. A Finnish/Sami word meaning "enemy".

Trivia from the movie Pathfinder:
The villains in the film, the "tjuder", are not supposed to be vikings, as some sources claim. Tjud or chud is a term historically applied to several Finnic peoples, in the early Russian annals. They often appear in Sami stories (like the one on which this film is based) as traditional, generic villains. Vikings where a trade among the Norse (Scandinavian) Germanic tribes. Note that the clothing and weaponry of the "tjuder" in the film are very different to the ones used by vikings. The script actually stated the "tjuder" to be eastern. But the filmmakers felt it would be offensive to Russian viewers so they made up a language for them to speak, making their origin rather vague.

The internet origins are more likely from the movie "CHUD: Cannibalistic Humanoid Underground Dwellers" because of the "underground dwellers" (basement dwellers) aspect and it's pleasing onomatopoeia. It sounds like an epithet or curse. It has the same vocal feeling as saying "Fuck". The interesting flip-side to using it as an insult against non-corporate-aligned anti-shills (apart from the fact that most trannies who use it are dwellers in mommy's basement themselves) is that in the movie it is revealed the actual meaning of the acronym is the very anti-corporate anti-cover-up: "Chemical Hazard Urban Disposal". Referencing the VERY real practice of local governments and corporation burying toxic industrial chemicals in urban centers. https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/missouri-elementary-school-radioactive-waste-was-found-will-switch-vir-rcna52881

"CHUD" in it's deepest semantic meaning is anti-institutional, anti-corporate and anti-authoritarian. Also, anti-poison and anti-corruption. All things the shills who use it represent, up to and including being toxic industrial chemical dumps themselves.

There was a dark age in science, which started when the Romans conquered the Hellenistic world and put an end to all the (slow, disorganised) progress that was being madr by Greeks. Romans closed down the Platonic Academy and Aristotle's Lyceum, burnt down the Library of Alexandria, murdered Archimedes. And not a single scientific advancement was made by Romans or under Roman domination.

That dark age ended after the Paris condemnations of 1277, when scholastic thinkers at Catholic universities started to think beyond Aristotle and following Catholic principles such as the belief in an ordered mathematical universe, or the practice to allow for doubt on all theories. This is what led to the Scientific Revolution.

His brother that died had learned everything about the ayys and was following the plan, he represented humanity trying to tame and exploit the ayys and the universe more broadly. Jake goes in like a big baby and is forced to go by instinct, which submits him to living in the moment. The fact that he switches bodies reinforces this idea of transience and how we are only briefly coherent beings in a stream of consciousness. It symbolically and literally explains his transformation as someone who was fighting fate and trying to circumvent it to someone who accepted reality completely and went with the flow. The fight against humanity is purely ideological or spiritual, not the silly literal dimensions of the movie where flying lizards fight robots or whatever. Those are symbolism.

posts.com: In the films, Umbrella is a multinational tech/biotech company. They make a shitload of money selling bioweapons to world governments. But how can they prove the bioweapons are effective? If they performed real-world tests that shit would get traced back to them. So they came up with a brilliant idea. Build a huge undersea complex with test environments. Moscow, New York, a generic suburban town, Tokyo. So they run some simulations showing how effective their weapons are, and use the data from New York to sell a weapon to Russia. Use the data from Russia to sell a weapon the US. Suppose China wants to pony up a few billion dollars for some sweet bioweapons. Well, Umbrella have a Japanese test environment to show off how effective their weapons are at eradicating the Nipponese menace. The Red Queen was put in charge of running the complex, and they haven't been selling any weapons for a long time because everyone is dead. But they do have clone manufacturing still running, and it is very likely that although it isn't explicitly stated, a lot of the helmeted Umbrella operatives whose faces aren't seen throughout the series are clones from the 50 base templates like Alice, Rain, Shade, JD, and of course Carlos and others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The sequels never recapture the magic but they are never boring or formulaic. And despite 6 movies over 15 years it never truly shits the bed. Paul Anderson and Jeremy Bolt kept a firm hand on things because Paul hated what happened to the second Mortal Kombat film. And Alien vs Predator 2 being nigh-unwatchable dogshit probably reinforced his fear of shitty cash grab sequels.

Very noticably, Anderson and Bolt tried to keep as many of the same people bwtween movies, whether they be actors, composers, editors, VFX people, cinetographers, second unit directors. Anderson might be an auteur, but he strongly believes in keeping the crew together. And that energy is why Apocalypse and Extinction largely stayed on track despite Anderson being busy on other movies.

My thesis is that the bigger a corporation gets, and the longer it's been around, the more incompetent it gets. The old founder generation has moved on, and you get idiots and money men rising through the ranks who fundamentally don't understand the appeal of the product or how to connect to customers. > War of the Cities: Meanwhile, Iraq's air force also began carrying out strategic bombing raids against Iranian cities. While Iraq had launched numerous attacks with aircraft and missiles against border cities from the beginning of the war and sporadic raids on Iran's main cities, this was the first systematic strategic bombing that Iraq carried out during the war. This would become known as the "War of the Cities". With the help of the USSR and the west, Iraq's air force had been rebuilt and expanded.[134] Meanwhile, Iran, due to sanctions and lack of spare parts, had heavily curtailed its air force operations. Iraq used Tu-22 Blinder and Tu-16 Badger strategic bombers to carry out long-range high-speed raids on Iranian cities, including Tehran. Fighter-bombers such as the Mig-25 Foxbat and Su-22 Fitter were used against smaller or shorter range targets, as well as escorting the strategic bombers.[134] Civilian and industrial targets were hit by the raids,[178] and each successful raid inflicted economic damage from regular strategic bombing.[134] In response, the Iranians deployed their F-4 Phantoms to combat the Iraqis, and eventually they deployed F-14s as well. By 1986, Iran also expanded their air defense network heavily to relieve the pressure on the air force. By later in the war, Iraqi raids primarily consisted of indiscriminate missile attacks[citation needed]while air attacks were used only on fewer, more important targets.[179] Starting in 1987, Saddam also ordered several chemical attacks on civilian targets in Iran, such as the town of Sardasht.[180]

wrong. it's about getting it in front of the right people who have money to burn who are trying to make a movie because it's their dream as well, but they don't have talent they just have money. so they throw it at people hoping to catch the content wave.

once the movie is made and has any positive word of mouth, you do the festival circuit and then a streaming service picks it up for distribution. this is where the producer makes their money back, and the creatives get pennies. the goal here is to have something cheap, simple and effective enough that the streamer comes back to the creative team again (based on secured rights) and throw more money at it.

this is how names are built these days. writing good content is the fast track. the hard way is the directing/acting route because everyone wants to be behind the camera or in front of the camera. no one wants to give their baby up to literal whos and watch their art get destroyed, but i don't care. i'll kill my darlings for a paycheck all day if it means my name in neons.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>177952926
Most anime is based on a manga. Manga is written by a single person and even when they get big and get more assistants it's usually just the one guy writing the story. If there are any assistants they are there just to help with art.
It's a single person doing his best to write something good, but he isn't a writer, he has to have more talent in drawing and things like character design than in writing.
A single person writing a story wouldn't be an issue, that's literally how books are written but mangaka aren't writers and can't write a book. Their entire writing consists of a few speech bubbles and they will never improve as writers. Books also don't come out with weekly updates. If someone writes a book they'll finish it and have drafts, and have people read it before publishing. With manga you just have a chapter come out and once it's out it's out. You can't go back and change it and you can't read the entire thing to see if it's bad. You can be many chapters in and still believe that the writer may know what he is doing.

Manga get big based on their art and some kind of a hook like a catchy title or a cool premise. By the time it's apparent that the writer has no idea what he is doing the manga will already have a fanbase and will have signed the rights to make an anime.
